posts.author: pwp1cx

posts.content: Hi, If you using the THINGSPEAKWRITE function in MATLAB Analysis app, you can specify the timestamp by using the 'TimeStamp' parameter. Here is an example - Note that you will have to replace the values with those corresponding to your channel: channelID = 12342;value = 10;timestamp = datetime('8/31/2015 9:22:01');write_API_Key = '12ADGDFGWER23423';thingSpeakWrite(channelID, value, 'TimeStamp', timestamp, 'WriteKey', write_API_Key)Find further information about the THINGSPEAKWRITE function here:https://thingspeak.com/docs/matlab_analysis#thingSpeakWriteIf instead you are using the Update Channel Feed API, then you can specify the 'created_at' parameter to specify the timestamp. Find further information about the update channel feed API here:https://thingspeak.com/docs/channels#update_feedThanks,Adarsh

posts.content: I'm trying to use ThingSpeak, and I would to understand how to use channels and fields.First of all, why a channel has 8 fields ? Why 8 and not 16 or 5 ?Then how are we supposed to use a channel ?Is a channel supposed to represent an object with several sensors ? Let's take an example :In my house, I have 5 rooms, in each of them I want to measure temperature, humidity and the light intensity.Do I need to create a channel for each room ? Or is it a good idea to create one channel for the temperature, one for humidity and one for lights ?Thank
posts.author: DAS

posts.content: A channel is accessed by a single API key so most likely you want to group some sensors connected to the same device into a channel.  Each channel can only be updated every 15 seconds minimum.The maximum fields per channel of 8 appears to be an arbitrary decision of the original developers for reasons unknown. The basic graph pages display all fields for a single channel on a page so that may influence your decision to group by room or parameter although you can now easily combine data from various channels using the matlab visualistion app.

posts.content: Thanks for all the great info and links... will take a while to read all that!If we compare Raspberry PI vs Arduino on those points, can you or someone else help                                                             RP           Arduino====================================PriceEase of adding WifiEase of programmingFlexibilitySizeSupportWhich one is the winner?
posts.author: Simon Filiatrault

posts.content: RaspPi and Ardiino are quite different beasts used for very different purposes so comparision is quite hard.  RaspPi is a tiny computer that can do most things your laptop can do, although not as fast- just plug in a monitor and keyboard.  Arduino has no display, no keyboard and requires another computer to program it (you can, in fact, use your RaspPi to program your Arduino)PriceArduino $3-$20, RaspPi $20-$60Ease of adding WifiArduino:  can use ESP8266 board via serial $3.  RaspPi can use off-the-shelf USB Wifi stick  $5-$20Ease of programmingArduino: can only use one language, a variant of C, need more powerful system to write programs and upload to board.  RaspPi has a wide variety of programming languages available eg perl, python, php, C, shell etc and can be programming with a keyboard and a HDMI-compatible monitor.FlexibilityRaspPi is more flexibleSizearduino comes in a range of form factors some of which are very small (almost as small as a bottle-top in some cases).  The new RaspPi zero is also quite compact but the standard RaspPi will occupy the palm of your hand once all the peripherals are connected.SupportBoth have really great communities http://forum.arduino.cc  and https://www.raspberrypi.org/forums/Which one is the winner?The answer is- it depends.An arduino, with careful programming, can run a single task for a year on a set of AA batteries but the RaspPi will flatten the same batteries in a few hours.The arduino inputs tend to be more tolerant of mistakes in the wiring than RaspPi.Arduino is cheap enough to blow upRaspPi has no analog inputs.I'd recommend getting both if time and budget permit.

posts.content: moballa,The MATLAB function 'thingSpeakPlot' documentation (https://thingspeak.com/docs/matlab_visualizations#thingSpeakPlot) shows that the function accepts three 'types' of inputs: vector, scalar, and matrix. The default input is a vector. However, if a matrix is specified, each column of the matrix is treated a separate series. For example, see the 'Create Matrix Line Plot' example. The MATLAB code 'magic(4)' uses the MATLAB function 'magic' (http://www.mathworks.com/help/matlab/ref/magic.html) returns a 4x4 matrix. The example figure clearly shows 4 lines with 4 points per line. The MATLAB function 'thingSpeakPlot' requires a square matrix if a single X,Y matrix pair is provided. However, the MATLAB function 'thingSpeakPlot' can plot multiple vectors of varying sizes if the inputs are provided as separate arguments, for example:thingSpeakPlot(x1, y1, x2, y2, ect...)MATLAB visualization functions accept 'lineSpecs' name-value parameters. The 'Create Plot with Specific Line Properties' example in the 'thingSpeakPlot' documentation shows different 'lineSpec' examples. The full set of name-value pairs are listed further down in the documentation.In the scenario above, additional logic is require to partition the data into different columns of a matrix.
